projects.title: Minty Game Engine
projects.description: 3D game engine and editor, made with C++ and Vulkan.
projects.tech: C++, Visual Studio, Vulkan, GLFW, many more...
body: The Minty Game Engine is a hobby project that I started in 2023, following Unity's pricing model change. After that disaster, I decided the best option for me was to create my own game engine. I have all of the skills, and I have done it before, more or less.
I have learned about and created the game engine with the following technologies:
Technologies
Vulkan

Vulkan is a low level 3D graphics library, written for C++. It's very popular due to its constant updates, company backing, multi-platform support, and many other things. However, due to it being so low level, it has its own challenges to learn and use, much more so than something such as its older brother library, OpenGL.
Experience
All of the following projects helped me create this one:
<ul>
• Minty (game engine)

• Audio
  • 2D graphics
• 327 Craft
• Venging
• 3D graphics
• The Void Above

• Mesh building
  • Shaders
• Ultimate Console Engine

projects.title: Terrain Generation Tech Demo
projects.description: A 3D procedural generation terrain tool.
projects.motivation: COM S 437 (Computer Game and Media Programming) technical presentation
body: The Terrain Generation Tech Demo was a really fun project to work on. Procedural generation has been a topic I have been quite fond of, so when I was told to select a topic for a technical presentation for my Computer Game and Media Programming class, it was a no brainer. Using two different blogs from Red Blob Games (who is awesome, by the way), I combined them together to create a cool little demo.

I started off using Red Blob's Polygonal Map Generation for Games blog, which I think is really cool and interesting. Using polygons is a different approach than what I have done in the past, so I thought, why not?

This project started out with some basic HTML, CSS, and JavaScript with WebGL2. I used what I had learned from my computer graphics class I had taken to throw this together quick, as I thought it would be easy and provide me more flexibility than something such as Unity. I also felt like Unity might have been overkill for such a project, plus, this is cool, and I wanted to see if I could create something useful with my newfound skills.

After working on this for a few days, time was running up before I had to demo this, so I decided to simplify a bit, and base it a little more off of Red Blob's Making Maps with Noise Functions blog instead. This is the one I was more familiar with. I did get quite far with the polygons: the mesh is actually created from polygons still, which is triangulated so it can be rendered with WebGL. The height and moisture maps are still created using noise (thank you Auburn for FastNoiseLite, it is amazing.) However, I believe it turned out quite well.
Anyways, enough yapping. If you want to check it out, please do! It can run in your browser.

projects.title: 327 Craft
projects.description: A 2D terminal game, inspired by Minecraft.
projects.motivation: COM S 327 (Advanced Programming Techniques) final project
body: 327 Craft was a final project that I made for my advanced programming techniques class (COM S 327). For the class itself, we created a Pokemon rogue game in the terminal, starting in C, and transitioning to C++ over the course of the semester. That project was fun, and had many of its own challenges and features. Some of the things implemented in that were chunk loading, asset (text) loading, general user interfaces, djikstra's algorithm for the enemies, as well as a combat system. I essentually made a small game engine for that game: which I used parts of for 327 Craft.

The final project for the class was open ended: we could create whatever we wanted, as long as it had an arguable amount of challenges in it. Most students created a connect 4 game or something else: I wanted to test myself with my new C and C++ skills I had picked up and improved upon over the semester, so I combined it with my existing game development knowledge. Most of what I had known (such as using noise and terrain generation, etc.) I had learned from when I made The Void Above.

The game itself had several features. Aside from being highly configurable using the csv files, the base game had several features. It had infinite procedural land generation, with 4 different biomes. Each biome also had different types of terrain, such as trees. The terrain would also spawn clouds in the sky, and ores underground, which was a fun little touch, to spice up the sky and ground.

In addition to the terrain generation, the player was also able to mine and place blocks. All the player could place was wood planks, but, you know, the thought was there. Here's a couple images of mining and building:

If I had taken the game further, there also would have been a system for crafting. I only made this within a week. Well, kinda- like I said, most of the 'engine' code was ripped from the Pokemon game that we had made for the class. Most of the code I wrote within that week had to do with the terrain generation and file reading.Despite this, I did at least create a barebones inventory system that would allow you to view what you had, and would update as you collect resources:
By navigating up and down, you could view more information for each item. Of course, they were labeled by their numerical ID, and that could have been their name, but it is what it is.
This game was created on Linux, so if you have Linux, you're in luck! If you feel like digging around the source code, you can find it on my GitHub page.

projects.title: The Legend of Mitchell
projects.description: A 2D platformer, featuring my girlfriend.
body: The Legend of Mitchell is a last minute game that I created for my girlfriend for Valentine's day, as a gift. I was struggling to come up with a Valentine's day gift for my girlfriend, and five days before the day, I thought it would be cool to make a game. So, that is what I did. For the next 5 days, I put myself into a 1 person game jam, attempting to crank out an entire game, all based on her.

For designing the game, I didn't put too much thought into it. Most of that was due to the time constraint. The idea was that I was going to create a Mario clone, but with Sage as the main character. And, since Sage is the main character, then I must be the one in peril. I thought it was a fun take on the whole thing. The boss of the game, of course, had to be somebody who wants to take me from her- so, I made it my friend Devin. You can see them in the main menu screenshot. ;)
The beginning of the game involves some basic challenges for her to figure out, such as some enemies I knew she would loathe: muchrooms, green olives, and onions. All foods she hates.

For a gimmick, I decided to make Sage so she could shrink, and become smaller. Why is that? All because, in real life, she is much shorter than I. So why not double down? It has many of its own advantages, and it especially does in this game.
And of course, it wouldn't be fun if she couldn't use her height to her advantage!

The game ended up having 3 total levels (that's all I had time for.) The first one was a fun introduction, the second was a challenge level, and the last was a boss fight. At the end, she would jump onto a green heart (her favorite color), which would fly her away to the next level:

And lastly, here is the introduction to the boss fight. Devin actually gave me some reference pictures for his face (which I sketched), and also helped me with designing the boss fight as well as the dialogue. I think it turned out great.

All in all, this was a fun, but also stressful project to work on. For me personally, I wanted to see how far I could push myself. For 5 days, I think this was great. However, more importantly, Sage thought it was great too. She cried happy tears :)

projects.title: Biggest Balls in the West
projects.description: A crazy western pinball game, that takes real balls to play.
projects.motivation: 2021 Fall Game Jam, hosted by the Game Development Club at ISU (exhibition)
body: The Biggest Balls in the West was a really fun game to work on. At the time, I was itching to create another game jam game. I was the president of the Game Development Club at Iowa State University for 2 years at that point, and hadn't participated in one since before then. I convinced the other officers of the club to create a game with me, and this is what we created.

Our goal for this game was to create a pinball game, similar to Sonic Spinball or Kirby's Pinball Land. The art on the sides of the game is supposed to represent the side art of a pinball machine, and the game can be found in the center.

Upon hitting start, the player is greeted with a quick and dirty instruction manual. After holding down space, the ball will be fired into the game. The Biggest Balls in the West is a procedural game, with random rooms. As you progress up the tower, you can collect points. But don't take too much time: the tower will start to sink into the quicksand it sits on eventually! At the top, you can fight one of four bosses. My personal favorites are the tumbleweed and the tire, which are also cutely depicted on the side art.

The tumbleweed boss, you must hit it several times, as it spins and rolls in and out of view. The tire spins around, but can only be damaged if you thread the needle to the inside. I'm really happy with this game, and it was a lot of fun to work on. Please play it on my itch page if you think its cool, I'd really appreciate it!
